description: From Middle English quaveren, frequentative form of quaven, cwavien (“to tremble”), equivalent to quave +‎ -er. Cognate with Low German quabbeln (“to quiver”), German quabbeln, quappeln (“to quiver”). More at quave, quab, quiver.

entries.meaning: A trembling of the voice, as in speaking or singing.
(music) an eighth note, drawn as a crotchet (quarter note) with a tail.

verbs.description: quaver (third-person singular simple present quavers, present participle quavering, simple past and past participle quavered)

entries.meaning: To shake in a trembling manner.
(intransitive) To use the voice in a trembling manner, as in speaking or singing.

examples: We shall hear her quavering them  […]  to some sprightly airs of the opera.
